docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a pregnant obstetrician-gynecologist, I agree that in rural areas, vaginal birth after Caesarean would not be appropriate in the absence of staff doctors to perform an immediate C-section if necessary.
docs.abstract: Dr Deborah Gahr letter holds that vaginal birth after Caesarean section is safe option in well-equipped hospitals0
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    As a pregnant obstetrician-gynecologist, I agree that in rural areas, vaginal birth after Caesarean would not be appropriate in the absence of staff doctors to perform an immediate C-section if necessary.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some federally financed sex education programs that teach an abstinence-only approach have factual errors and are ineffective, a Congressional report says. The report, by the Democratic staff of the House Government Reform Committee for Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, says the programs provide ''false, misleading or distorted information'' about contraception, abortion, sexually transmitted diseases and sexual stereotypes.
docs.abstract: Report by Democratic staff of House Government Reform Committee says some federally financed sex education programs that teach abstinence-only approach have factual errors and are ineffective; Bush administration supports abstinence-only education and plans to spend $170 million on such programs next year, more than twice as much as in 2001 (M)
docs.snippet: Some federally financed sex education programs that teach an abstinence-only approach have factual errors and are ineffective, a Congressional report says.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a recent poll, just 32 percent of Italians surveyed said it was right for religion to have an influence on the laws of the state. Yet crucifixes hang in public schools. Abortion is legal here and not much debated anymore. Yet religious sentiment runs deep enough that Friday night comes in Italy with the adventures of Don Matteo, handsome crime-solving priest. One study, in fact, showed that 27 percent of all protagonists on public television are priests, nuns or saints (though it is also hard to ignore that other large percentage on Italian television: near-naked women).

headline.main: Italy's Church and State: A Mostly Happy Union

docs.abstract: Italy, European nation where religion and state have mingled most, manages issue without much of bitter, absolute argument seen in US; Italy is not exempt from counterpoint argued angrily in Europe, about whether Continent has become so secular as to be hostile to religion, but 1,700 years of debate and hard experience seem to have allowed church and state to settle into almost indistinct whole; result is that while only 32 percent of Italians believe religion should have secular influence, crucifixes hang in public schools without much comment, and abortion is legal and not much debated; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In the European nation where religion and state have mingled most, disagreements are less bitter than in the U.S.
